protocol_name: Finding the core vs flexible microbiome
protocol_name_html: Finding the core vs flexible microbiome
description:
In a study comparing obese versus lean twins, Turnbaugh and colleagues found that there were "shared microbial genes among sampled individuals, comprising an extensive, identifiable 'core microbiome' at the gene, rather than at the organismal lineage level".  
This means that despite having differences in bacterial composition, the "core" functional repertoire of microbiome remains the same in obese versus lean twins.  
In this tutorial, we are going to explore these functional differences in two lean twins (TS1 and TS2) and two obese twins (TS19 and TS20) from this study.   

Turnbaugh, Peter J., et al. "A core gut microbiome in obese and lean twins."nature 457.7228 (2009): 480-484.

components.data:
Look for the obese lean data files in the community data directory:
 /iplant/home/shared/imicrobe/class/obese_lean
SRR029687 - lean T1
SRR029692 - lean T2
SRR029686 -obese T19
SRR029688 - obese T20
You will use the fasta files in this directory for the next step.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:

components.data:
Click on the Apps button, navigate to experimental->imicrobe->uproc
Click on uproc
Click on "Required Args"
Use the Browse function to navigate to " /iplant/home/shared/imicrobe/class/obese_lean/SRR029687.fasta" under "Sequence file"
Run uproc with default parameters on the fasta file
Repeat for all of the other fasta files in the obese lean dataset

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Finding the core vs flexible microbiome
source_data.protocol_name: Finding the core vs flexible microbiome
source_data.protocol_name_html: Finding the core vs flexible microbiome
source_data.annotation:
Some people are having issues with running the sra toolkit on the hpc.  You can download these files from iPlant too:
% module load irods
% icd /iplant/home/shared/imicrobe/class
% iget -r obese_lean

Some people are having issues with running the sra toolkit on the hpc.  You can download these files from iPlant too:
% module load irods
% icd /iplant/home/shared/imicrobe/class

components.data:
Load irods on the hpc
% module load irods
If this is the first time you have used irods, you will need to run:
% iinit
use the configurations:
host-> data.iplantcollaborative.org; port -> 1247; zone -> iplant; user-> your iplant user; login -> your iplant login

components.data:
Copy your files from the uproc runs to iPlant and rename them by the file_name.uproc
% mkdir obese_lean
% cd obese_lean
% icd /iplant/home/your_user/analyses/uproc_SRR029687-your-analysis
% iget uproc-out
% mv uproc-out SRR029687.uproc
Repeat for each fasta file

components.data:
Write a program that finds all kegg ids that are "core" to each file (in T1, T2, T19, and T20) and have at least 50 read matches.
The uproc output files have the following:
<kegg_id>,<read count>
"core" means that the kegg id is present in each of the uproc files
Program name: get_core.pl
Output: should be a list of kegg ids
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Write a program that finds all kegg ids that are "core" to each file (in T1, T2, T19, and T20) and have at least 50 read matches.
The uproc output files have the following:
<kegg_id>,<read count>
"core" means that the kegg id is present in each of the uproc files
Program name: get_core.pl
Output: should be a list of kegg ids

components.data:
Write a program that finds all kegg ids that are "variable" in the files (in T1, T2, T19, and T20) and have at least 50 read matches.
The uproc output files have the following:
<kegg_id>,<read count>
"variable" means that the kegg id is present in 1-3 uproc files, but not all 4.
Program name: get_variable.pl
Output: should be a list of kegg ids
components.name: Description

components.data: Combine the two programs into a single program: get_core_and_variable.pl
